text: In the past God spoke to our ancestors through the prophets at many times and in various ways,
speaker: Narrator

text: but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, and through whom also he made the universe.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Son is the radiance of God’s glory and the exact representation of his being, sustaining all things by his powerful word. After he had provided purification for sins, he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he became as much superior to the angels as the name he has inherited is superior to theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For to which of the angels did God ever say,
‘You are my Son;
    today I have become your Father’?
Or again,
‘I will be his Father,
    and he will be my Son’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And again, when God brings his firstborn into the world, he says,
‘Let all God’s angels worship him.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
In speaking of the angels he says,
‘He makes his angels spirits,
    and his servants flames of fire.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
He also says,
‘In the beginning, Lord, you laid the foundations of the earth,
    and the heavens are the work of your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will perish, but you remain;
    they will all wear out like a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will roll them up like a robe;
    like a garment they will be changed.
But you remain the same,
    and your years will never end.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
To which of the angels did God ever say,
‘Sit at my right hand
    until I make your enemies
    a footstool for your feet’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are not all angels ministering spirits sent to serve those who will inherit salvation?
speaker: Narrator

text: We must pay the most careful attention, therefore, to what we have heard, so that we do not drift away.
speaker: Narrator

text: For since the message spoken through angels was binding, and every violation and disobedience received its just punishment,
speaker: Narrator

text: how shall we escape if we ignore so great a salvation? This salvation, which was first announced by the Lord, was confirmed to us by those who heard him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God also testified to it by signs, wonders and various miracles, and by gifts of the Holy Spirit distributed according to his will.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not to angels that he has subjected the world to come, about which we are speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But there is a place where someone has testified:
‘What is mankind that you are mindful of them,
    a son of man that you care for him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You made them a little lower than the angels;
    you crowned them with glory and honour
speaker: Narrator

text:
and put everything under their feet.’
In putting everything under them, God left nothing that is not subject to them. Yet at present we do not see everything subject to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we do see Jesus, who was made lower than the angels for a little while, now crowned with glory and honour because he suffered death, so that by the grace of God he might taste death for everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: In bringing many sons and daughters to glory, it was fitting that God, for whom and through whom everything exists, should make the pioneer of their salvation perfect through what he suffered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both the one who makes people holy and those who are made holy are of the same family. So Jesus is not ashamed to call them brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And again,
‘I will put my trust in him.’
And again he says,
‘Here am I, and the children God has given me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the children have flesh and blood, he too shared in their humanity so that by his death he might break the power of him who holds the power of death – that is, the devil –
speaker: Narrator

text: and free those who all their lives were held in slavery by their fear of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: For surely it is not angels he helps, but Abraham’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason he had to be made like them, fully human in every way, in order that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest in service to God, and that he might make atonement for the sins of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he himself suffered when he was tempted, he is able to help those who are being tempted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, holy brothers and sisters, who share in the heavenly calling, fix your thoughts on Jesus, whom we acknowledge as our apostle and high priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was faithful to the one who appointed him, just as Moses was faithful in all God’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus has been found worthy of greater honour than Moses, just as the builder of a house has greater honour than the house itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every house is built by someone, but God is the builder of everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Moses was faithful as a servant in all God’s house,’ bearing witness to what would be spoken by God in the future.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Christ is faithful as the Son over God’s house. And we are his house, if indeed we hold firmly to our confidence and the hope in which we glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So, as the Holy Spirit says:
‘Today, if you hear his voice,
speaker: Narrator

text:
do not harden your hearts
as you did in the rebellion,
    during the time of testing in the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
where your ancestors tested and tried me,
    though for forty years they saw what I did.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So I declared on oath in my anger,
    “They shall never enter my rest.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: See to it, brothers and sisters, that none of you has a sinful, unbelieving heart that turns away from the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But encourage one another daily, as long as it is called ‘Today’, so that none of you may be hardened by sin’s deceitfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have come to share in Christ, if indeed we hold our original conviction firmly to the very end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As has just been said:
‘Today, if you hear his voice,
    do not harden your hearts
    as you did in the rebellion.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Who were they who heard and rebelled? Were they not all those Moses led out of Egypt?
speaker: Narrator

text: And with whom was he angry for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose bodies perished in the wilderness?
speaker: Narrator

text: And to whom did God swear that they would never enter his rest if not to those who disobeyed?
speaker: Narrator

text: So we see that they were not able to enter, because of their unbelief.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since the promise of entering his rest still stands, let us be careful that none of you be found to have fallen short of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we also have had the good news proclaimed to us, just as they did; but the message they heard was of no value to them, because they did not share the faith of those who obeyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now we who have believed enter that rest, just as God has said,
‘So I declared on oath in my anger,
    “They shall never enter my rest.”’
And yet his works have been finished since the creation of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For somewhere he has spoken about the seventh day in these words: ‘On the seventh day God rested from all his works.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And again in the passage above he says, ‘They shall never enter my rest.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore since it still remains for some to enter that rest, and since those who formerly had the good news proclaimed to them did not go in because of their disobedience,
speaker: Narrator

text:
God again set a certain day, calling it ‘Today’. This he did when a long time later he spoke through David, as in the passage already quoted:
‘Today, if you hear his voice,
    do not harden your hearts.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For if Joshua had given them rest, God would not have spoken later about another day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There remains, then, a Sabbath-rest for the people of God;
speaker: Narrator

text: for anyone who enters God’s rest also rests from their works, just as God did from his.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us, therefore, make every effort to enter that rest, so that no one will perish by following their example of disobedience.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the word of God is alive and active. Sharper than any double-edged sword, it penetrates even to dividing soul and spirit, joints and marrow; it judges the thoughts and attitudes of the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nothing in all creation is hidden from God’s sight. Everything is uncovered and laid bare before the eyes of him to whom we must give account.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we have a great high priest who has ascended into heaven, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold firmly to the faith we profess.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we do not have a high priest who is unable to feel sympathy for our weaknesses, but we have one who has been tempted in every way, just as we are – yet he did not sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us then approach God’s throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every high priest is selected from among the people and is appointed to represent the people in matters related to God, to offer gifts and sacrifices for sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is able to deal gently with those who are ignorant and are going astray, since he himself is subject to weakness.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is why he has to offer sacrifices for his own sins, as well as for the sins of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And no one takes this honour on himself, but he receives it when called by God, just as Aaron was.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And he says in another place,
‘You are a priest for ever,
    in the order of Melchizedek.’
speaker: Narrator

text: During the days of Jesus’ life on earth, he offered up prayers and petitions with fervent cries and tears to the one who could save him from death, and he was heard because of his reverent submission.
speaker: Narrator

text: Son though he was, he learned obedience from what he suffered
speaker: Narrator

text: and, once made perfect, he became the source of eternal salvation for all who obey him
speaker: Narrator

text: and was designated by God to be high priest in the order of Melchizedek.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have much to say about this, but it is hard to make it clear to you because you no longer try to understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you the elementary truths of God’s word all over again. You need milk, not solid food!
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who lives on milk, being still an infant, is not acquainted with the teaching about righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: But solid food is for the mature, who by constant use have trained themselves to distinguish good from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let us move beyond the elementary teachings about Christ and be taken forward to maturity, not laying again the foundation of repentance from acts that lead to death, and of faith in God,
speaker: Narrator

text: instruction about cleansing rites, the laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God permitting, we will do so.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is impossible for those who have once been enlightened, who have tasted the heavenly gift, who have shared in the Holy Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: who have tasted the goodness of the word of God and the powers of the coming age
speaker: Narrator

text: and who have fallen away, to be brought back to repentance. To their loss they are crucifying the Son of God all over again and subjecting him to public disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Land that drinks in the rain often falling on it and that produces a crop useful to those for whom it is farmed receives the blessing of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But land that produces thorns and thistles is worthless and is in danger of being cursed. In the end it will be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though we speak like this, dear friends, we are convinced of better things in your case – the things that have to do with salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: God is not unjust; he will not forget your work and the love you have shown him as you have helped his people and continue to help them.
speaker: Narrator

text: We want each of you to show this same diligence to the very end, so that what you hope for may be fully realized.
speaker: Narrator

text: We do not want you to become lazy, but to imitate those who through faith and patience inherit what has been promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: When God made his promise to Abraham, since there was no one greater for him to swear by, he swore by himself,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, ‘I will surely bless you and give you many descendants.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And so after waiting patiently, Abraham received what was promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: People swear by someone greater than themselves, and the oath confirms what is said and puts an end to all argument.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because God wanted to make the unchanging nature of his purpose very clear to the heirs of what was promised, he confirmed it with an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: God did this so that, by two unchangeable things in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled to take hold of the hope set before us may be greatly encouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have this hope as an anchor for the soul, firm and secure. It enters the inner sanctuary behind the curtain,
speaker: Narrator

text: where our forerunner, Jesus, has entered on our behalf. He has become a high priest for ever, in the order of Melchizedek.
speaker: Narrator

text: This Melchizedek was king of Salem and priest of God Most High. He met Abraham returning from the defeat of the kings and blessed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Abraham gave him a tenth of everything. First, the name Melchizedek means ‘king of righteousness’; then also, ‘king of Salem’ means ‘king of peace’.
speaker: Narrator

text: Without father or mother, without genealogy, without beginning of days or end of life, resembling the Son of God, he remains a priest for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just think how great he was: even the patriarch Abraham gave him a tenth of the plunder!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the law requires the descendants of Levi who become priests to collect a tenth from the people – that is, from their fellow Israelites – even though they also are descended from Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: This man, however, did not trace his descent from Levi, yet he collected a tenth from Abraham and blessed him who had the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: And without doubt the lesser is blessed by the greater.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the one case, the tenth is collected by people who die; but in the other case, by him who is declared to be living.
speaker: Narrator

text: One might even say that Levi, who collects the tenth, paid the tenth through Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: because when Melchizedek met Abraham, Levi was still in the body of his ancestor.
speaker: Narrator

text: If perfection could have been attained through the Levitical priesthood – and indeed the law given to the people established that priesthood – why was there still need for another priest to come, one in the order of Melchizedek, not in the order of Aaron?
speaker: Narrator

text: For when the priesthood is changed, the law must be changed also.
speaker: Narrator

text: He of whom these things are said belonged to a different tribe, and no one from that tribe has ever served at the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is clear that our Lord descended from Judah, and in regard to that tribe Moses said nothing about priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what we have said is even more clear if another priest like Melchizedek appears,
speaker: Narrator

text: one who has become a priest not on the basis of a regulation as to his ancestry but on the basis of the power of an indestructible life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is declared:
‘You are a priest for ever,
    in the order of Melchizedek.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The former regulation is set aside because it was weak and useless
speaker: Narrator

text: (for the law made nothing perfect), and a better hope is introduced, by which we draw near to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was not without an oath! Others became priests without any oath,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but he became a priest with an oath when God said to him:
‘The Lord has sworn
    and will not change his mind:
    “You are a priest for ever.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this oath, Jesus has become the guarantor of a better covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there have been many of those priests, since death prevented them from continuing in office;
speaker: Narrator

text: but because Jesus lives for ever, he has a permanent priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore he is able to save completely those who come to God through him, because he always lives to intercede for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such a high priest truly meets our need – one who is holy, blameless, pure, set apart from sinners, exalted above the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Unlike the other high priests, he does not need to offer sacrifices day after day, first for his own sins, and then for the sins of the people. He sacrificed for their sins once for all when he offered himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law appoints as high priests men in all their weakness; but the oath, which came after the law, appointed the Son, who has been made perfect for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the main point of what we are saying is this: we do have such a high priest, who sat down at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: and who serves in the sanctuary, the true tabernacle set up by the Lord, not by a mere human being.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every high priest is appointed to offer both gifts and sacrifices, and so it was necessary for this one also to have something to offer.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he were on earth, he would not be a priest, for there are already priests who offer the gifts prescribed by the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: They serve at a sanctuary that is a copy and shadow of what is in heaven. This is why Moses was warned when he was about to build the tabernacle: ‘See to it that you make everything according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But in fact the ministry Jesus has received is as superior to theirs as the covenant of which he is mediator is superior to the old one, since the new covenant is established on better promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if there had been nothing wrong with that first covenant, no place would have been sought for another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God found fault with the people and said:
‘The days are coming, declares the Lord,
    when I will make a new covenant
with the people of Israel
    and with the people of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will not be like the covenant
    I made with their ancestors
when I took them by the hand
    to lead them out of Egypt,
because they did not remain faithful to my covenant,
    and I turned away from them,
declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the covenant I will establish with the people of Israel
    after that time, declares the Lord.
I will put my laws in their minds
    and write them on their hearts.
I will be their God,
    and they will be my people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No longer will they teach their neighbours,
    or say to one another, “Know the Lord,”
because they will all know me,
    from the least of them to the greatest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I will forgive their wickedness
    and will remember their sins no more.’
speaker: Narrator

text: By calling this covenant ‘new’, he has made the first one obsolete; and what is obsolete and outdated will soon disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the first covenant had regulations for worship and also an earthly sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: A tabernacle was set up. In its first room were the lampstand and the table with its consecrated bread; this was called the Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behind the second curtain was a room called the Most Holy Place,
speaker: Narrator

text: which had the golden altar of incense and the gold-covered ark of the covenant. This ark contained the gold jar of manna, Aaron’s staff that had budded, and the stone tablets of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above the ark were the cherubim of the Glory, overshadowing the atonement cover. But we cannot discuss these things in detail now.
speaker: Narrator

text: When everything had been arranged like this, the priests entered regularly into the outer room to carry on their ministry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But only the high priest entered the inner room, and that only once a year, and never without blood, which he offered for himself and for the sins the people had committed in ignorance.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit was showing by this that the way into the Most Holy Place had not yet been disclosed as long as the first tabernacle was still functioning.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is an illustration for the present time, indicating that the gifts and sacrifices being offered were not able to clear the conscience of the worshipper.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are only a matter of food and drink and various ceremonial washings – external regulations applying until the time of the new order.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Christ came as high priest of the good things that are now already here, he went through the greater and more perfect tabernacle that is not made with human hands, that is to say, is not a part of this creation.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not enter by means of the blood of goats and calves; but he entered the Most Holy Place once for all by his own blood, so obtaining eternal redemption.
speaker: Narrator

text: The blood of goats and bulls and the ashes of a heifer sprinkled on those who are ceremonially unclean sanctify them so that they are outwardly clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more, then, will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself unblemished to God, cleanse our consciences from acts that lead to death, so that we may serve the living God!
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason Christ is the mediator of a new covenant, that those who are called may receive the promised eternal inheritance – now that he has died as a ransom to set them free from the sins committed under the first covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the case of a will, it is necessary to prove the death of the one who made it,
speaker: Narrator

text: because a will is in force only when somebody has died; it never takes effect while the one who made it is living.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is why even the first covenant was not put into effect without blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had proclaimed every command of the law to all the people, he took the blood of calves, together with water, scarlet wool and branches of hyssop, and sprinkled the scroll and all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘This is the blood of the covenant, which God has commanded you to keep.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, he sprinkled with the blood both the tabernacle and everything used in its ceremonies.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, the law requires that nearly everything be cleansed with blood, and without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was necessary, then, for the copies of the heavenly things to be purified with these sacrifices, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ did not enter a sanctuary made with human hands that was only a copy of the true one; he entered heaven itself, now to appear for us in God’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor did he enter heaven to offer himself again and again, the way the high priest enters the Most Holy Place every year with blood that is not his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise Christ would have had to suffer many times since the creation of the world. But he has appeared once for all at the culmination of the ages to do away with sin by the sacrifice of himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as people are destined to die once, and after that to face judgment,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Christ was sacrificed once to take away the sins of many; and he will appear a second time, not to bear sin, but to bring salvation to those who are waiting for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The law is only a shadow of the good things that are coming – not the realities themselves. For this reason it can never, by the same sacrifices repeated endlessly year after year, make perfect those who draw near to worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, would they not have stopped being offered? For the worshippers would have been cleansed once for all, and would no longer have felt guilty for their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those sacrifices are an annual reminder of sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
with burnt offerings and sin offerings
    you were not pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, “Here I am – it is written about me in the scroll –
    I have come to do your will, my God.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: First he said, ‘Sacrifices and offerings, burnt offerings and sin offerings you did not desire, nor were you pleased with them’– though they were offered in accordance with the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, ‘Here I am, I have come to do your will.’ He sets aside the first to establish the second.
speaker: Narrator

text: And by that will, we have been made holy through the sacrifice of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Day after day every priest stands and performs his religious duties; again and again he offers the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when this priest had offered for all time one sacrifice for sins, he sat down at the right hand of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and since that time he waits for his enemies to be made his footstool.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by one sacrifice he has made perfect for ever those who are being made holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit also testifies to us about this. First he says:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘This is the covenant I will make with them
    after that time, says the Lord.
I will put my laws in their hearts,
    and I will write them on their minds.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he adds:
‘Their sins and lawless acts
    I will remember no more.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And where these have been forgiven, sacrifice for sin is no longer necessary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, brothers and sisters, since we have confidence to enter the Most Holy Place by the blood of Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: by a new and living way opened for us through the curtain, that is, his body,
speaker: Narrator

text: and since we have a great priest over the house of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: let us draw near to God with a sincere heart and with the full assurance that faith brings, having our hearts sprinkled to cleanse us from a guilty conscience and having our bodies washed with pure water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us hold unswervingly to the hope we profess, for he who promised is faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let us consider how we may spur one another on towards love and good deeds,
speaker: Narrator

text: not giving up meeting together, as some are in the habit of doing, but encouraging one another – and all the more as you see the Day approaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we deliberately keep on sinning after we have received the knowledge of the truth, no sacrifice for sins is left,
speaker: Narrator

text: but only a fearful expectation of judgment and of raging fire that will consume the enemies of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who rejected the law of Moses died without mercy on the testimony of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more severely do you think someone deserves to be punished who has trampled the Son of God underfoot, who has treated as an unholy thing the blood of the covenant that sanctified them, and who has insulted the Spirit of grace?
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know him who said, ‘It is mine to avenge; I will repay,’ and again, ‘The Lord will judge his people.’
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a dreadful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember those earlier days after you had received the light, when you endured in a great conflict full of suffering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes you were publicly exposed to insult and persecution; at other times you stood side by side with those who were so treated.
speaker: Narrator

text: You suffered along with those in prison and joyfully accepted the confiscation of your property, because you knew that you yourselves had better and lasting possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: So do not throw away your confidence; it will be richly rewarded.
speaker: Narrator

text: You need to persevere so that when you have done the will of God, you will receive what he has promised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For,
‘In just a little while,
    he who is coming will come
    and will not delay.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
And,
‘But my righteous one will live by faith.
    And I take no pleasure
    in the one who shrinks back.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But we do not belong to those who shrink back and are destroyed, but to those who have faith and are saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the ancients were commended for.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith we understand that the universe was formed at God’s command, so that what is seen was not made out of what was visible.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abel brought God a better offering than Cain did. By faith he was commended as righteous, when God spoke well of his offerings. And by faith Abel still speaks, even though he is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Enoch was taken from this life, so that he did not experience death: ‘He could not be found, because God had taken him away.’ For before he was taken, he was commended as one who pleased God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And without faith it is impossible to please God, because anyone who comes to him must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who earnestly seek him.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Noah, when warned about things not yet seen, in holy fear built an ark to save his family. By his faith he condemned the world and became heir of the righteousness that is in keeping with faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abraham, when called to go to a place he would later receive as his inheritance, obeyed and went, even though he did not know where he was going.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he made his home in the promised land like a stranger in a foreign country; he lived in tents, as did Isaac and Jacob, who were heirs with him of the same promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he was looking forward to the city with foundations, whose architect and builder is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And by faith even Sarah, who was past childbearing age, was enabled to bear children because she considered him faithful who had made the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so from this one man, and he as good as dead, came descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and as countless as the sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these people were still living by faith when they died. They did not receive the things promised; they only saw them and welcomed them from a distance, admitting that they were foreigners and strangers on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: People who say such things show that they are looking for a country of their own.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they had been thinking of the country they had left, they would have had opportunity to return.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, they were longing for a better country – a heavenly one. Therefore God is not ashamed to be called their God, for he has prepared a city for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abraham, when God tested him, offered Isaac as a sacrifice. He who had embraced the promises was about to sacrifice his one and only son,
speaker: Narrator

text: even though God had said to him, ‘It is through Isaac that your offspring will be reckoned.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham reasoned that God could even raise the dead, and so in a manner of speaking he did receive Isaac back from death.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau in regard to their future.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Jacob, when he was dying, blessed each of Joseph’s sons, and worshipped as he leaned on the top of his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Joseph, when his end was near, spoke about the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt and gave instructions concerning the burial of his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses’ parents hid him for three months after he was born, because they saw he was no ordinary child, and they were not afraid of the king’s edict.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses, when he had grown up, refused to be known as the son of Pharaoh’s daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: He chose to be ill-treated along with the people of God rather than to enjoy the fleeting pleasures of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He regarded disgrace for the sake of Christ as of greater value than the treasures of Egypt, because he was looking ahead to his reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he left Egypt, not fearing the king’s anger; he persevered because he saw him who is invisible.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he kept the Passover and the application of blood, so that the destroyer of the firstborn would not touch the firstborn of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the people passed through the Red Sea as on dry land; but when the Egyptians tried to do so, they were drowned.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the walls of Jericho fell, after the army had marched round them for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the prostitute Rahab, because she welcomed the spies, was not killed with those who were disobedient.
speaker: Narrator

text: And what more shall I say? I do not have time to tell about Gideon, Barak, Samson and Jephthah, about David and Samuel and the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: who through faith conquered kingdoms, administered justice, and gained what was promised; who shut the mouths of lions,
speaker: Narrator

text: quenched the fury of the flames, and escaped the edge of the sword; whose weakness was turned to strength; and who became powerful in battle and routed foreign armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Women received back their dead, raised to life again. There were others who were tortured, refusing to be released so that they might gain an even better resurrection.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some faced jeers and flogging, and even chains and imprisonment.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were put to death by stoning; they were sawn in two; they were killed by the sword. They went about in sheepskins and goatskins, destitute, persecuted and ill-treated –
speaker: Narrator

text: the world was not worthy of them. They wandered in deserts and mountains, living in caves and in holes in the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were all commended for their faith, yet none of them received what had been promised,
speaker: Narrator

text: since God had planned something better for us so that only together with us would they be made perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we are surrounded by such a great cloud of witnesses, let us throw off everything that hinders and the sin that so easily entangles. And let us run with perseverance the race marked out for us,
speaker: Narrator

text: fixing our eyes on Jesus, the pioneer and perfecter of faith. For the joy that was set before him he endured the cross, scorning its shame, and sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider him who endured such opposition from sinners, so that you will not grow weary and lose heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: In your struggle against sin, you have not yet resisted to the point of shedding your blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And have you completely forgotten this word of encouragement that addresses you as a father addresses his son? It says,
‘My son, do not make light of the Lord’s discipline,
    and do not lose heart when he rebukes you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because the Lord disciplines the one he loves,
    and he chastens everyone he accepts as his son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Endure hardship as discipline; God is treating you as his children. For what children are not disciplined by their father?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are not disciplined – and everyone undergoes discipline – then you are not legitimate, not true sons and daughters at all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, we have all had human fathers who disciplined us and we respected them for it. How much more should we submit to the Father of spirits and live!
speaker: Narrator

text: They disciplined us for a little while as they thought best; but God disciplines us for our good, in order that we may share in his holiness.
speaker: Narrator

text: No discipline seems pleasant at the time, but painful. Later on, however, it produces a harvest of righteousness and peace for those who have been trained by it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, strengthen your feeble arms and weak knees.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Make level paths for your feet,’ so that the lame may not be disabled, but rather healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make every effort to live in peace with everyone and to be holy; without holiness no one will see the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: See to it that no one falls short of the grace of God and that no bitter root grows up to cause trouble and defile many.
speaker: Narrator

text: See that no one is sexually immoral, or is godless like Esau, who for a single meal sold his inheritance rights as the oldest son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, as you know, when he wanted to inherit this blessing, he was rejected. Even though he sought the blessing with tears, he could not change what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not come to a mountain that can be touched and that is burning with fire; to darkness, gloom and storm;
speaker: Narrator

text: to a trumpet blast or to such a voice speaking words that those who heard it begged that no further word be spoken to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they could not bear what was commanded: ‘If even an animal touches the mountain, it must be stoned to death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The sight was so terrifying that Moses said, ‘I am trembling with fear.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have come to Mount Zion, to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem. You have come to thousands upon thousands of angels in joyful assembly,
speaker: Narrator

text: to the church of the firstborn, whose names are written in heaven. You have come to God, the Judge of all, to the spirits of the righteous made perfect,
speaker: Narrator

text: to Jesus the mediator of a new covenant, and to the sprinkled blood that speaks a better word than the blood of Abel.
speaker: Narrator

text: See to it that you do not refuse him who speaks. If they did not escape when they refused him who warned them on earth, how much less will we, if we turn away from him who warns us from heaven?
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time his voice shook the earth, but now he has promised, ‘Once more I will shake not only the earth but also the heavens.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The words ‘once more’ indicate the removing of what can be shaken – that is, created things – so that what cannot be shaken may remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we are receiving a kingdom that cannot be shaken, let us be thankful, and so worship God acceptably with reverence and awe,
speaker: Narrator

text: for our ‘God is a consuming fire.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep on loving one another as brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not forget to show hospitality to strangers, for by so doing some people have shown hospitality to angels without knowing it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Continue to remember those in prison as if you were together with them in prison, and those who are ill-treated as if you yourselves were suffering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Marriage should be honoured by all, and the marriage bed kept pure, for God will judge the adulterer and all the sexually immoral.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So we say with confidence,
‘The Lord is my helper; I will not be afraid.
    What can mere mortals do to me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember your leaders, who spoke the word of God to you. Consider the outcome of their way of life and imitate their faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be carried away by all kinds of strange teachings. It is good for our hearts to be strengthened by grace, not by eating ceremonial foods, which is of no benefit to those who do so.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have an altar from which those who minister at the tabernacle have no right to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high priest carries the blood of animals into the Most Holy Place as a sin offering, but the bodies are burned outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so Jesus also suffered outside the city gate to make the people holy through his own blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us, then, go to him outside the camp, bearing the disgrace he bore.
speaker: Narrator

text: For here we do not have an enduring city, but we are looking for the city that is to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through Jesus, therefore, let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise – the fruit of lips that openly profess his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not forget to do good and to share with others, for with such sacrifices God is pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have confidence in your leaders and submit to their authority, because they keep watch over you as those who must give an account. Do this so that their work will be a joy, not a burden, for that would be of no benefit to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray for us. We are sure that we have a clear conscience and desire to live honourably in every way.
speaker: Narrator

text: I particularly urge you to pray so that I may be restored to you soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God of peace, who through the blood of the eternal covenant brought back from the dead our Lord Jesus, that great Shepherd of the sheep,
speaker: Narrator

text: equip you with everything good for doing his will, and may he work in us what is pleasing to him, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory for ever and ever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers and sisters, I urge you to bear with my word of exhortation, for in fact I have written to you quite briefly.
speaker: Narrator

text: I want you to know that our brother Timothy has been released. If he arrives soon, I will come with him to see you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet all your leaders and all the Lord’s people. Those from Italy send you their greetings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grace be with you all.
speaker: Narrator
